paragraphs.zh-tw: That's how we traveled in the year 1900. That's an open buggy. It doesn't have heating. It doesn't have air conditioning.
paragraphs.en: 這是我們 1900 年用的交通工具 輕便敞篷馬車，沒有裝暖氣 也沒有裝冷氣

paragraphs.zh-tw: That horse is pulling it along at one percent of the speed of sound, and the rutted dirt road turns into a quagmire of mud anytime it rains. That's a Boeing 707.
paragraphs.en: 那隻馬 以 1% 的聲速前進 而布滿車輪痕跡的泥濘小路 一下雨就成了沼澤地 這是波音 707 客機

paragraphs.zh-tw: Only 60 years later, it travels at 80 percent of the speed of sound, and we don't travel any faster today because commercial supersonic air travel turned out to be a bust. So I started wondering and pondering, could it be that the best years of American economic growth are behind us? And that leads to the suggestion, maybe economic growth is almost over.
paragraphs.en: 只過了 60 年 就能以 80% 的聲速移動 而現在我們沒有更快的交通工具 因為超音速商務飛機 最後失敗了 所以我開始思索 會不會美國經濟最蓬勃發展的年代 已經過去了？ 這也意味著，或許經濟成長 幾乎已經結束了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Some of the reasons for this are not really very controversial. There are four headwinds that are just hitting the American economy in the face.
paragraphs.en: 有些結束的原因沒有太大的爭議 現在有四大困境正迎面襲擊 美國現在的經濟實力

paragraphs.zh-tw: They're demographics, education, debt and inequality. They're powerful enough to cut growth in half.
paragraphs.en: 包括人口統計、教育、債務及不平等的問題 這些問題足以減少一半的成長

paragraphs.zh-tw: So we need a lot of innovation to offset this decline. And here's my theme: Because of the headwinds, if innovation continues to be as powerful as it has been in the last 150 years, growth is cut in half.
paragraphs.en: 所以我們需要大量創新來抵銷經濟下滑的趨勢 這就是我的主題：因為這些困境 假如創新的表現能和過去 150 年一樣亮眼 經濟成長會減半

paragraphs.zh-tw: If innovation is less powerful, invents less great, wonderful things, then growth is going to be even lower than half of history. Now here's eight centuries of economic growth.
paragraphs.en: 假如創新力沒有進步 無法再發明更多有用的東西 那麼經濟成長將比不上過去的一半 這是過去八個世紀經濟成長的表現

paragraphs.zh-tw: The vertical axis is just percent per year of growth, zero percent a year, one percent a year, two percent a year. The white line is for the U.K., and then the U.S.
paragraphs.en: 縱軸代表每年成長的百分比 一年 0%、1% 或 2% 白線代表英國，後段是美國

paragraphs.zh-tw: takes over as the leading nation in the year 1900, when the line switches to red. You'll notice that, for the first four centuries, there's hardly any growth at all, just 0.2 percent.
paragraphs.en: 在 1900 年成為世界強權 也就是紅色線段的部分 大家可以注意到，前面四個世紀 幾乎沒有任何成長，只有 0.2%

paragraphs.zh-tw: Then growth gets better and better. It maxes out in the 1930s, '40s and '50s, and then it starts slowing down, and here's a cautionary note.
paragraphs.en: 接著成長越來越快 在 1930、1940 及 1950 年有最高的經濟成長率 然後成長逐漸趨緩，要注意的是

paragraphs.zh-tw: That last downward notch in the red line is not actual data. That is a forecast that I made six years ago that growth would slow down to 1.3 percent.
paragraphs.en: 紅線中最後一次下滑的部分 不是實際的資料 是我六年前做的預測 經濟成長將下滑至 1.3%

paragraphs.zh-tw: But you know what the actual facts are? You know what the growth in per-person income has been in the United States in the last six years? Negative. This led to a fantasy.
paragraphs.en: 但是你們知道實際數據是多少嗎？ 你們知道過去六年，美國每人所得 成長率是多少嗎？ 是負數 假設一下

paragraphs.zh-tw: What if I try to fit a curved line to this historical record? I can make the curved line end anywhere I wanted, but I decided I would end it at 0.2, just like the U.K. growth for the first four centuries. Now the history that we've achieved is that we've grown at 2.0 percent per year over the whole period, 1891 to 2007, and remember it's been a little bit negative since 2007.
paragraphs.en: 我試著以曲線表示這份歷史紀錄 我可以自己決定曲線在哪裡結束 我認為會在 0.2 的部分 就跟英國前面四個世紀一樣 歷史上我們的經濟成長表現是 從 1891 年到 2007 年，每年都成長了 2% 而且別忘了從 2007 年就開始出現負成長

paragraphs.zh-tw: But if growth slows down, instead of doubling our standard of living every generation, Americans in the future can't expect to be twice as well off as their parents, or even a quarter [more well off than] their parents. Now we're going to change and look at the level of per capita income.
paragraphs.en: 如果成長趨緩 而不是每一代的生活水準都有兩倍成長 未來美國人無法過的比自己的父母加倍幸福 或甚至連他們幸福的四分之一都不到 現在我們來看看每人平均所得水準

paragraphs.zh-tw: The vertical axis now is thousands of dollars in today's prices. You'll notice that in 1891, over on the left, we were at about 5,000 dollars.
paragraphs.en: 縱軸是以現在物價來衡量的價格 大家可以看到在 1891 年，左手邊的部分 大約是平均 5000 元

paragraphs.zh-tw: Today we're at about 44,000 dollars of total output per member of the population. Now what if we could achieve that historic two-percent growth for the next 70 years? Well, it's a matter of arithmetic.
paragraphs.en: 現在大約每人總產出是 四萬四千元 萬一接下來的 70 年，我們可以達到 2% 成長的表現，結果會是如何呢？ 這就是算術上的問題了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Two-percent growth quadruples your standard of living in 70 years. That means we'd go from 44,000 to 180,000.
paragraphs.en: 2% 的成長率，70 年後是現在生活水準的四倍 代表我們將從四萬四成長到十八萬

paragraphs.zh-tw: Well, we're not going to do that, and the reason is the headwinds. The first headwind is demographics.
paragraphs.en: 但我們做不到 原因就是那些困境 第一個困境是人口統計

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a truism that your standard of living rises faster than productivity, rises faster than output per hour, if hours per person increased. And we got that gift back in the '70s and '80s when women entered the labor force.
paragraphs.en: 我們都知道，如果每小時的人力增加 生活水準會成長得比生產力更快 也比每小時的產出更快 從 70 和 80 年代 女性投入勞動力，就可以看的出來

paragraphs.zh-tw: But now it's turned around. Now hours per person are shrinking, first because of the retirement of the baby boomers, and second because there's been a very significant dropping out of the labor force of prime age adult males who are in the bottom half of the educational distribution.
paragraphs.en: 但現在情況不同了 現在每小時的人力逐漸在萎縮 第一個原因是因為嬰兒潮出生的人退休了 第二個原因是因為 大量男性壯年人口的勞動力下降 這些人分布於受教育人口的底層

paragraphs.zh-tw: The next headwind is education. We've got problems all over our educational system despite Race to the Top.
paragraphs.en: 第二個困境是教育 儘管推動了「力爭上游」的教育改革計畫 整個教育體制還是有問題

paragraphs.zh-tw: In college, we've got cost inflation in higher education that dwarfs cost inflation in medical care. We have in higher education a trillion dollars of student debt, and our college completion rate is 15 points, 15 percentage points below Canada.
paragraphs.en: 大學裡，高等教育的成本膨脹 使得醫療照顧的成本萎縮 高等教育的學生負債高達一兆美元 而我們大學的畢業率 是 15 個百分點，比加拿大低 15 個百分點

paragraphs.zh-tw: We have a lot of debt. Our economy grew from 2000 to 2007 on the back of consumers massively overborrowing.
paragraphs.en: 我們有很多的債務 我們的經濟從 2000 年到 2007 年有所成長 是因為消費者大量的借貸

paragraphs.zh-tw: Consumers paying off that debt is one of the main reasons why our economic recovery is so sluggish today. And everybody of course knows that the federal government debt is growing as a share of GDP at a very rapid rate, and the only way that's going to stop is some combination of faster growth in taxes or slower growth in entitlements, also called transfer payments.
paragraphs.en: 需要償還貸款的消費者 就是我們現在經濟蕭條的主因 而大家當然都知道 聯邦政府的公債也在持續上升 急速成為國內生產毛額的一部分 要阻止債務增加唯一的方法 是結合高稅率及低津貼的方式 也叫做轉移支付

paragraphs.zh-tw: And that gets us down from the 1.5, where we've reached for education, down to 1.3. And then we have inequality.
paragraphs.en: 這使得我們教育有的 1.5% 成長率 因負債下滑至 1.3% 最後是不平等的問題

paragraphs.zh-tw: Over the 15 years before the financial crisis, the growth rate of the bottom 99 percent of the income distribution was half a point slower than the averages we've been talking about before. All the rest went to the top one percent.
paragraphs.en: 金融危機前 15 年 底部 99% 所得分配的成長率 比我們之前所提過的平均成長率 還要低 0.5 個百分點 剩下的都是頂端 1%

paragraphs.zh-tw: So that brings us down to 0.8. And that 0.8 is the big challenge.
paragraphs.en: 因此使得我們的成長率下滑至 0.8% 這 0.8% 又是一大挑戰

paragraphs.zh-tw: Are we going to grow at 0.8? If so, that's going to require that our inventions are as important as the ones that happened over the last 150 years. So let's see what some of those inventions were.
paragraphs.en: 我們有 0.8% 的經濟成長率嗎？ 如果有，那我們的創新就必須 和過去 150 年的創新 一樣重要 我們來看看這些創新有哪些

paragraphs.zh-tw: If you wanted to read in 1875 at night, you needed to have an oil or a gas lamp. They created pollution, they created odors, they were hard to control, the light was dim, and they were a fire hazard.
paragraphs.en: 在 1875 年，如果你晚上想要讀書 你需要一盞油燈或煤氣燈 這些燈會造成污染，產生氣味 光線微弱，難以控制 還有火災的危險

paragraphs.zh-tw: By 1929, electric light was everywhere. We had the vertical city, the invention of the elevator.
paragraphs.en: 到了 1929 年，到處都有電燈 因為電梯的發明，我們有了向上發展的城市

paragraphs.zh-tw: Central Manhattan became possible. And then, in addition to that, at the same time, hand tools were replaced by massive electric tools and hand-powered electric tools, all achieved by electricity.
paragraphs.en: 曼哈頓的繁榮才能成真 除此之外，同時 手持工具被大量的電動工具 和手動操作的電動工具所取代 一切都歸功於電的發明

paragraphs.zh-tw: Electricity was also very helpful in liberating women. Women, back in the late 19th century, spent two days a week doing the laundry.
paragraphs.en: 電力對於婦女解放也有很大的幫助 19 世紀晚期，女性 一週花兩天的時間在洗衣服

paragraphs.zh-tw: They did it on a scrub board. Then they had to hang the clothes out to dry.
paragraphs.en: 用洗衣板洗衣服 然後還要把衣服拿出去晾乾

paragraphs.zh-tw: Then they had to bring them in. The whole thing took two days out of the seven-day week.
paragraphs.en: 再把衣服收進來 整個過程一個禮拜就花了兩天

paragraphs.zh-tw: And then we had the electric washing machine. And by 1950, they were everywhere.
paragraphs.en: 後來發明了洗衣機 到了 1950 年，已經普遍使用

paragraphs.zh-tw: But the women still had to shop every day, but no they didn't, because electricity brought us the electric refrigerator. Back in the late 19th century, the only source of heat in most homes was a big fireplace in the kitchen that was used for cooking and heating.
paragraphs.en: 但婦女還是得每天上街買菜 事實上不需要，因為電 帶動了冰箱的發明 19 世紀晚期，大部分家庭唯一的熱源 是廚房裡用來煮飯的大壁爐

paragraphs.zh-tw: The bedrooms were cold. They were unheated. But by 1929, certainly by 1950, we had central heating everywhere.
paragraphs.en: 臥房都很冷，沒有暖氣 但是到了 1929 年，更確定是到 1950 年 中央暖氣系統已無所不在

paragraphs.zh-tw: What about the internal combustion engine, which was invented in 1879? In America, before the motor vehicle, transportation depended entirely on the urban horse, which dropped, without restraint, 25 to 50 pounds of manure on the streets every day together with a gallon of urine. That comes out at five to 10 tons daily per square mile in cities.
paragraphs.en: 那麼 1879 年 發明的內燃機呢？ 在美國，車子發明以前 交通完全倚賴馬匹 牠們每天會在街道上無限制的 排放 25 到 50 磅的糞便 以及一加侖的尿液 城市每平方英里 一天會有 5 到 10 噸的排放量

paragraphs.zh-tw: Those horses also ate up fully one quarter of American agricultural land. That's the percentage of American agricultural land it took to feed the horses.
paragraphs.en: 那些馬還吃了美國四分之一的農地 這就是美國農地 用來養馬的比例

paragraphs.zh-tw: Of course, when the motor vehicle was invented, and it became almost ubiquitous by 1929, that agricultural land could be used for human consumption or for export. And here's an interesting ratio: Starting from zero in 1900, only 30 years later, the ratio of motor vehicles to the number of households in the United States reached 90 percent in just 30 years.
paragraphs.en: 當然，車子發明了以後 到 1929 年，幾乎已普遍使用 那些農地就能讓人使用 或是出口 這個數據很有趣，1900 年開始 只過了 30 年，美國每戶擁有車子的比率 從 0% 成長到 90%，只花了 30 年

paragraphs.zh-tw: Back before the turn of the century, women had another problem. All the water for cooking, cleaning and bathing had to be carried in buckets and pails in from the outside.
paragraphs.en: 在上個世紀之前 婦女還遇到另外一個難題 所有煮飯、清潔或梳洗的用水 都必須用水桶從外面裝回來

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a historical fact that in 1885, the average North Carolina housewife walked 148 miles a year carrying 35 tons of water. But by 1929, cities around the country had put in underground water pipes.
paragraphs.en: 這是 1885 年的史實 北卡羅來納州的家庭主婦 一年走了 145 英里，裝 35 噸的水 但是到了 1929 年，全國各城市 都建設了地下水道

paragraphs.zh-tw: They had put in underground sewer pipes, and as a result, one of the great scourges of the late 19th century, waterborne diseases like cholera, began to disappear. And an amazing fact for techno-optimists is that in the first half of the 20th century, the rate of improvement of life expectancy was three times faster than it was in the second half of the 19th century.
paragraphs.en: 他們鋪了下水道 因此，19 世紀晚期最嚴重的災難 透過水所傳染的疾病像霍亂，逐漸消失 對技術樂觀主義者來說，最驚人的是 20 世紀前半 平均壽命改善的速率 比 19 世紀後半 快了 3 倍

paragraphs.zh-tw: So it's a truism that things can't be more than 100 percent of themselves. And I'll just give you a few examples.
paragraphs.en: 所以理所當然你知道這已經是最好的表現了 我給大家舉一些例子

paragraphs.zh-tw: We went from one percent to 90 percent of the speed of sound. Electrification, central heat, ownership of motor cars, they all went from zero to 100 percent.
paragraphs.en: 我們從 0% 的聲速進步到 90% 電氣化、中央暖氣系統、汽車 都從無到有，0% 進步到 100%

paragraphs.zh-tw: Urban environments make people more productive than on the farm. We went from 25 percent urban to 75 percent by the early postwar years.
paragraphs.en: 比起農場，城市的環境讓我們更有生產力 戰後初期，城市化的比率 從 25% 上升至 75%

paragraphs.zh-tw: What about the electronic revolution? Here's an early computer. It's amazing. The mainframe computer was invented in 1942.
paragraphs.en: 那麼電子方面的革命呢？ 這是早期的電腦 非常驚人，大型電腦在 1942 年時發明

paragraphs.zh-tw: By 1960 we had telephone bills, bank statements were being produced by computers. The earliest cell phones, the earliest personal computers were invented in the 1970s.
paragraphs.en: 到了 1960 年，我們的電話和銀行帳單 都交由電腦處理 最早的手機、最早的個人電腦 都在 1970 年出現

paragraphs.zh-tw: The 1980s brought us Bill Gates, DOS, ATM machines to replace bank tellers, bar code scanning to cut down on labor in the retail sector. Fast forward through the '90s, we had the dotcom revolution and a temporary rise in productivity growth.
paragraphs.en: 1980 年代我們有了比爾蓋茲、磁碟作業系統 以及自動提款機，來取代銀行的出納員 條碼掃描器減少了零售業的人力 一下就到了 90 年代 我們有了網路革命 生產力一度上升

paragraphs.zh-tw: But I'm now going to give you an experiment. You have to choose either option A or option B.
paragraphs.en: 現在給大家做個實驗 只能選 A 或選 B

paragraphs.zh-tw: Option A is you get to keep everything invented up till 10 years ago. So you get Google, you get Amazon, you get Wikipedia, and you get running water and indoor toilets.
paragraphs.en: A 選項是你可以保留一直到 10 年前所發明的東西 所以你有谷歌、亞馬遜可以用 還有維基百科、自來水和室內廁所

paragraphs.zh-tw: Or you get everything invented to yesterday, including Facebook and your iPhone, but you have to give up, go out to the outhouse, and carry in the water. Hurricane Sandy caused a lot of people to lose the 20th century, maybe for a couple of days, in some cases for more than a week, electricity, running water, heating, gasoline for their cars, and a charge for their iPhones.
paragraphs.en: 或是 B 選項，你可以擁有直至今日發明的所有東西 包括臉書和蘋果的智慧型手機 但你必須放棄，你必須到外面 裝水回來 颶風桑迪讓許多人失去了 20 世紀的一切 也許是幾天 有些人超過一個禮拜 沒有電、自來水、暖氣和汽油 也沒辦法幫手機充電

paragraphs.zh-tw: The problem we face is that all these great inventions, we have to match them in the future, and my prediction that we're not going to match them brings us down from the original two-percent growth down to 0.2, the fanciful curve that I drew you at the beginning. So here we are back to the horse and buggy.
paragraphs.en: 現在的問題是，未來我們要有 比得上這些偉大發明的創新 而我預期，未來不會有更偉大的發明 我們從原來的 2% 成長率 下滑到我一開始畫的 0.2% 的未來預測 現在回到馬匹及馬車

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'd like to award an Oscar to the inventors of the 20th century, the people from Alexander Graham Bell to Thomas Edison to the Wright Brothers, I'd like to call them all up here, and they're going to call back to you. Your challenge is, can you match what we achieved? Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 我想頒個奧斯卡獎 給 20 世紀的發明家 從亞歷山大·格拉漢姆·貝爾 到湯瑪斯·愛迪生，再到萊特兄弟 我想請他們到這裡來 告訴大家 你們面臨的挑戰是：能不能戰勝我們的成就呢？ 謝謝大家

title: Robert Gordon The Death Of Innovation The End Of Growth
